me I think over my career I've maybe
interviewed 30,000 at least 30,000
people has been the estimation that I
have put from from sort of the math that
I've done. I interviewed 16 people
yesterday. 16 people. Yeah. 16 like
15-inute interviews like what 30 minutes
a piece. Yeah, 30 minutes a piece. It
has been centered around engineering
hiring and then broadened out around all
the rest of the disciplines around
building products and games. And then
now here at at the firm, it's sort of
across the entire landscape of of the
fund. I find that you can get a decent
degree of understanding of a person. You
can't do a deep functional interview.
You know, like if if you're trying to
assess if someone is a competent
engineer, you're not going to know right
away in 30 minutes, but you can start
getting a reasonable estimation of their
characteristics and behaviors and and
maybe general intelligence, stuff like
that, easily within, I think honestly,
10 to 15 minutes. And and within 30,
you've gotten, I think, a reasonable
understanding of general quality. One of
the biggest differentiators between
candidates, a thing that is not often
observed in interviews or or from, you
know, a typical prospect is what what I
call ownership mindset. So, an employee
mindset individual sees themselves at
odds with a business that they might be
employed by. They see the interview
process as something to overcome.
They're not necessarily trying to find
the right fit as if like they were
searching for a partner for a marriage.
They're just trying to get the marriage,
right? They're just like trying to win.
The truth is it's not a win to create a
relationship that is imperfect, right?
And so, if you're in the employee
mindset, you're thinking like, I want to
be a partner with the business. I want
to drive the business and I want the
business to make the right decision in
hiring someone, not necessarily myself.
In an interview process, I think that
means that you need to exhibit awareness
of that business. You have to be able to
give a cogent answer about why you want
to work there. You need to show them
that you're willing to not be selected.
And the way you do that is if they ask
you a question that you don't know, you
maybe say, "I don't know." If you have
experience that isn't a fit, you say,
"Oh, I haven't done that exact thing."
Right? I I just want to be very
transparent about where my skills are
and where they aren't so I can, you
know, come to the team with everyone
being on the same page about what we're
going to be able to do and accomplish.
To get a job in in big tech, number one,
you have to have relevant functional
skills and those are going to be really
job applicable. So, it's hard for me to
itemize them in detail here. If you come
to the table with that owner's mindset,
the mindset being that you want the
business to make the right decision and
that you are part of the business or
will be part of the business if you go
there, then that will set you way apart
from the contenders for the position
because the people interviewing you will
see like, oh, you want to come here and
help us. You aren't trying to take from
the organization and find ways to orient
yourself to be able to sort of like take
value. I tend to think that uh certain
methods to get noticed by recruiters
maybe haven't changed. Like is LinkedIn
and just shooting out resumes and
finding companies, job portals still the
primary way that you'd recommend someone
in the market looking for a job to just
go down those traditional paths or are
there anything new ways that you've
interfaced with candidates in this way?
If I'm a candidate and I've already
resolved that maybe the top five
companies aren't the place for me or I
haven't gotten a job now I now I need to
expand my focus right I need to look at
other alternatives that's the first
question is how much have you thought
about what industry what size of company
what sort of you know the frame of the
opportunities that you want to have in
focus once you have an an idea of that
how mature is the business and stuff
like that I think you should go to a
pitchbook or you should go to a crunch
base or whatever and you Start looking
at companies that were funded recently.
So try and figure out how recent the
funding, how, you know, significant the
funding, do they have solveny so they're
able to to grow a team. A lot of times
there will be all sorts of companies
that maybe they had like a Techrunch
article or something. You might have
missed it. But now when you go through
this data, you you'll suddenly realize
like, oh, there were 30 or 50 companies
in the past two months that raised
enough capital for for them to be able
to hire. You're not only knowing that
they're going to be hiring, you know,
that at least their investors had very
recent conviction about their prospects.
It's both that they have the capability
to hire you and that maybe you want to
hitch your wagon to theirs or whatever
the phrase is. I don't know what the
phrase is. Most candidates that I
interact with don't do do not know what
they want. So, if you can if you can
sort of reflect on why you want to be at
that stage of business, etc., It sets
you up for the next step which is now I
need to either apply or I need to you
know maybe reach out to people who work
in in these um organizations. LinkedIn
of course is a place that you can figure
out who works in these organizations. I
think it depends on the context of the
industry. Like if you're in a more
professional industry the likelihood
that they're on LinkedIn is higher. If
it's web 3 or crypto like probably not
on LinkedIn they're probably on on X,
right? And so just understanding the
environment and where you're operating
is is a critical consideration. But then
I think you should be writing to people
who work at that organization and when
you write to them it should be succinct
and clear and it should exhibit your
introspection about why you want to work
there. It shouldn't be more than a
paragraph or two though. So you have to
be able to si succinctly state what
you've done to research and why you
think that that's a a a convincing sort
of opportunity for you. And then you
should assume that 90% of your
outreaches will get ignored. Most
candidates, I think most people who are
never in sales, who are never in
recruiting, they think, "Oh, I sent five
messages. I got no responses. This is
clearly a failing strategy." The reality
is like, "No, you need to message a lot
more people." So, like, you should just
expect failure as the common outcome in
90ish% of cases. And maybe in 5 to 10%
of cases, they're going to write back to
you and be excited to have a
conversation. So, I think there's a
there's there's several le levels,
right? It's like, have you thought about
what you want? Then once you've
identified what you want, how do you go
after it? Are you willing to accept
failure as you know the the sort of like
consistent experience that you have and
not assign that to failure? Just
recognize that it's the work that's
required to get in front of the right
opportunities. I think dating and
marriage do in some ways sort of map to
searching for a job. In in sort of the
dating context, you get a a huge slew of
people who are not introspective, who
don't really know their intent when they
meet with partners. And the result is
that they have all sorts of fractious
relationships that don't yield, you
know, marriage or whatever it is that
they might be seeking. And then you have
some small subset of people who are very
targeted about what they're looking for
and they're far more likely to be
successful in sort of translating that
into the outcome that they want. How
many people do you think someone who's
seeking a partner meets in their life?
And how many do they actually end up
with? They talk to maybe hundreds or
thousands of people and they they maybe
end up partnering with one, two, maybe
three or four throughout their their
lifetime at least in a serious way. Jobs
are not dissimilar in that fashion. And
if you if you sort of reframe your job
search expectation around like I should
be meeting hundreds not dozens and that
should lead to maybe one, two or three
jobs. Then it sort of allows you to
accept like the failure as not being a
failure. Just literally the price of a
high quality job search that actually
lands you in a job that is probably
right for you and right for the
organization as well.
How do you think about networking in
this day and age? How to put oneself out
there? Should they be creating content?
Should they be going to events? Like
what's really out there? Referrals are
definitely advantageous for job seekers.
Meaning if if you're referred into the
organization, the likelihood of it
translating to a hire is just
astronomically higher than if you sort
of cold apply or you outreach directly
to a manager. The reality is referrals
are on the basis of relationships that
were likely forged long before the
referral occurred. Right? So like it's
not often that I meet someone at an
event and then two weeks later they
refer me to a job. um maybe there's some
like, you know, cascade of events that
later turn into that, but it's probably
two, three, five years down the road
where that's going to occur. So, if
you're job searching and you're like, I
need to network to actually service my
current job search, like you're too
late. Yeah. It's done. Like you you've
already up. So, like if if if you
are in that position, recognize like now
you need to overcome it through work.
And you can overcome it through work,
but most people don't want to deal with
that. instead they sort of want to feel
some sort of victim in this in this
situation. And the truth is you can feel
like a victim all you want. It's not
going to solve the problem of getting
you the job that you need to have. So if
you haven't already established the
network if you don't already have
referrals or referers, then yeah, hard
work is what's going to get you to the
place that you want to go. And I do not
believe for a second that any capable
person who puts in the hard work isn't
going to eventually find something that
is actually really valuable because most
people will not put in that work. That's
just the truth of most job seekers that
I've ever encountered. So network early.
If you have to use networking as a
function to get a job in the immediiacy,
you're probably too late. Or if you need
to build your network immediately. So
you can use your network if it's already
established. But if you're building it
to service your current job search, it's
probably too late.
What are some of like the favorite both
the favorite things you like to see in
rÃ©sumÃ©s, but also some absolute red
flags? Simplicity is the best.
Effectively what you want to do is make
sure that everything is quickly
understandable. Um, and what I mean from
a simplicity standpoint is like it
should be evident where you are working
at what time. There shouldn't be
overlaps. Even if there were overlaps,
you should be like thoughtful about how

don't even have a bunch of overlapping
time frames. Every single job should
have no more than five bullets. No line
should word rap where you know like the
bullet starts and then it it runs and
then it goes to a second line. I hate
that. Yeah. Well, the thing is for every
reader, they have to track it. And most

out there that suggests that recruiters
spend no more than seven seconds looking
at your resume. Wow. So, for every line
break that you have, you're inviting
them to basically tune out, spend an
extra like 0.1 second to have to like
scan the next line. Yeah. And to think.
They actually have to like think for a
second. What was the last word and
what's the word? You know, like they
actually have to read. Um, but most
recruiters are just looking at the
totality and they're they're honing in

that means that you need to really
determine what do I want to say here. I
don't want to itemize all of the effort
I put in, all of the work that I did.
Rather, for every line, I should
highlight the impact that I had. Right?
So, instead of me trying to have

Instead, I'm going to say, "While I was

maybe pride themselves at a certain

Like, how do those folks strike you as

effectively everything you're

what parts of your experience are

for most candidates like you would
suggest building side brands personal
brand some type of like maybe more

either something they can start now or

Underline unmindful. I think it's hard
to hurt yourself if the orientation that

thoughtful and if you're building a
personal brand, especially in in certain

channels, like I think it actively works

it's likely to fare for you in terms of
your interview process. Now, to be
clear, that might mean that you don't

that's not a net L. That's a W. You not

is a W because that will hopefully lead

fit for you. That's a good way to put
it. How much further do you go as far as
like stalking someone's LinkedIn or

want to go find a whole bunch of

life. If it returns a Twitter account, I
might go look, especially if it seems

example, if they're a marketer, you
know, I'm I'm probably going to go look
at their Twitter. third product person,
I might go look at their Twitter because
it might say something about who they
follow and they might have conversations
about product stuff. And so really the
channels that I'm going to go look at
are the channels where I think that
there's more relevant information about
their profession. So if it's an

in designers case, I might go search the

trying to learn about them as a

I'm not like watching Tik Toks of them
and like stuff like that. But if I
looked at their LinkedIn or I look at
their ex and they have interesting
behavior that seems like it would be

an organization, it will definitely

having a career. They just seem to have
a a a personal like vendetta or
something. Yeah. Just some drive to like
write every wrong. It's really a
question of judgment. Okay. It's not
even about their political opinions,
right? It's like how does this serve you
as a job seeker? And why are you
choosing to do this on this platform by
doing it the way that you are? I can
already assume a couple things about
you, which is that you care more about
what you personally want to discuss than
you do about necessarily showing up well
for your next job or for right sort of
like focusing on on your work. Do some
other recruiters go deeper than I? I'm
certain they do. But ultimately, most
recruiters, they want to help you get
the job. This is a very important
understanding. It's like the recruiter
is on your side that their job is to

don't think you're going to get in much

circumstances where it's different, but
I don't think that's the case.

I guess for earlier, more junior roles

People who are just students and who are

maybe at a a very large organization
